Initially, General Braddock refused Washington's advice to dispense with wagons, insisting on pulling all his accustomed equipment through the unblazed wilderness, which caused the force to become badly dispersed over almost 20 miles. Despite the defeat being one of the worst in British colonial history, Washington emerged as a "bullet proof hero of the Monongahela."
